trips_4o.polished_text: With rapid advancements in dialogue systems (Bae et al., 2022) and creative writing (Swanson et al., 2021), LLMs have evolved beyond being mere tools for daily tasks. LLMs have become increasingly prevalent in education (Kasneci et al., 2023; AlAfnan et al., 2023). In the technology industry, they play a crucial role, significantly influencing society (Dong et al., 2023). Bias in LLMs is concerning because their social influence can exacerbate legal and ethical issues, impacting decision-making and societal norms by shaping perceptions and actions, particularly in areas like media representation and automated decision-making processes. Researchers like Weidinger et al. (2021) and Deshpande et al. (2023) have examined how LLMs affect societal values and ethics, revealing significant implications for policy and practice, including issues of bias and fairness. Previous studies by Gupta et al. (2022) highlight gender bias in NLP models, revealing disparities in the interpretation of gender-related data, which often leads to stereotypes and unequal treatment in automated systems. Sheng et al. (2019) further emphasized these biases, particularly in how models handle gender, affecting perceptions and interactions in settings like hiring practices and social media communication. Research on gender bias in LLMs often focuses on specific English tasks, typically using single-dimensional evaluation methods (Wan et al., 2023; Kotek et al., 2023). However, these studies often overlook that LLMs receive varied instructions for different circumstances, reflecting gender bias in multiple aspects, such as language nuances and societal context. Considering the diverse language backgrounds of LLM users and the multilingual capabilities of LLMs (Lai et al., 2023; Bang et al., 2023; Rathje et al., 2023; Shi et al., 2023), it is crucial to explore how specific language features, such as syntax and semantics, along with cultural influences like societal norms and communication styles, impact gender bias in diverse languages, affecting user perception and interaction. Different languages show varying degrees of gender bias in LLM outputs, with certain languages demonstrating more pronounced biases, which can significantly influence user experience and perceptions, particularly in terms of how users interact with technology. Recognizing these variations is vital for addressing and mitigating biases, ensuring LLMs are equitable and culturally aware across applications, thereby enhancing fairness, inclusivity, and accuracy by adapting to different cultural contexts. Our study addresses the limitations in evaluating gender bias in LLMs by focusing on LLM-driven conversations. We employ a comprehensive approach that examines linguistic and cultural contexts to understand bias dynamics. We present three quantitative measures that clearly reveal the multidimensional aspects of gender bias in LLMs, highlighting disparities in representation and sentiment, and providing a nuanced view of bias manifestations, such as differences in gender portrayal and emotional tone. Based on these measures, we conduct experiments in six languages using state-of-the-art LLMs like GPT-3 and GPT-4 (Brown et al., 2020). This enables a detailed comparison of gender bias levels and nuances across different languages, offering insights into linguistic and cultural influences. Our methods allow a detailed analysis of lexical and sentiment aspects of gender bias across languages, offering insights into cross-linguistic patterns and differences, and revealing the subtleties of bias that vary by language and culture, such as how language structure and cultural narratives influence bias expression.

trips_4o.polished_text: This year, I decided to do more to help those less fortunate than me. Around Christmas time, I truly began to see how many people were struggling around me. I knew it happened, but somehow I never really thought too much about it. About 2 weeks ago now, I was walking down the road on my way to get a cup of coffee before doing some Christmas shopping and I saw a bunch of businesses with people curled up outside them. They were trying to stay warm with blankets, sleeping bags, and hats. Those were the lucky ones. I saw others huddled in doorways, trying to keep warm and survive with empty cups or signs in front of them. They were pleading for help with basic necessities every person deserves. I'm not sure why I noticed today. Perhaps it was because I was spending money on unnecessary Christmas gifts while some people couldn't afford a hot meal. I spotted one guy sitting with a small blanket wrapped around a dog that looked like it had seen better days. I checked my pockets for cash and realized I had very little. I stopped to talk to him and learned he had been laid off 2 years ago, lost his home, and had no nearby family. He told me that he found the dog abandoned one day and decided to keep it. The money he gets from panhandling goes toward feeding his dog, his best friend. I asked if he was hungry, and he looked surprised, saying he was starving and lucky to eat anything each day. He asked a nearby friend to watch his dog, and we went to get lunch. I picked up sandwiches for others I saw, hot cups of coffee, and a bag of dog food for his buddy. We delivered the food, and I have never seen such joy before. It was a wonderful moment; I made many people happy, but most importantly, I made myself happy.

Meanwhile, your other hand should be placed approximately 2-3 feet (or 0.6-0.9 meters) down from the top of the paddle. For instance, if you are paddling on the left side of the boat, your right hand will serve as your inside hand. In this scenario, you would grip the top of the paddle with your right hand, while your left hand should be positioned lower on the paddle shaft. The goal is to extend the paddle's end as far forward as possible without having to stand up from your seat. For example, when paddling on the left side of the canoe, insert the paddle into the water directly in front of you, to the left of the boat. Keep the end of the paddle submerged underwater, and push with your top hand while pulling back with the bottom hand to propel the paddle backward. Once the paddle is behind you and cannot go any further back, lift it out of the water and smoothly swing it back in front of you to its initial position. By repeating this process, you will propel the canoe forward while maintaining a straight course and preventing it from going in circles.

If the bowman is paddling on the left side of the canoe, the sternman should paddle on the right side to maintain balance. Both paddlers should synchronize their strokes, with paddles entering and exiting the water simultaneously. The bowman, positioned at the front of the canoe, is responsible for setting the pace, while the sternman should adjust their paddling rhythm to match. A "J" stroke is a subtle backward stroke used to steer the canoe; for a leftward direction, the sternman should execute a "J" stroke on the left side. Conversely, to steer right, the sternman would perform a "J" stroke on the right side. The more pronounced the backward stroke, the sharper the canoe's turn will be. A draw maneuver involves extending the paddle away from the boat and vertically positioning it so that only the flat end is submerged in water. Then, pull the paddle toward the boat's edge for the desired effect. During sharp turns, both the bowman and sternman should perform a draw on opposite sides of the canoe. To execute a sharp left turn, the sternman should draw on the right side, and for a sharp right turn, the draw should be on the left side.

In the unfortunate event of tipping over, secure the paddles and any belongings under the seats of the overturned canoe. Hold onto the canoe, and swim towards the nearest shore for safety. When canoeing in a river with a strong current, avoid swimming against it; instead, hold onto the canoe until the current eases, allowing you to safely reach the shore. If you find yourself far from shore, try flipping the canoe back over with the help of your partner. trips_4o.polished_text: Recent work in mining medical texts focuses on building deep learning models for tasks like mortality and diagnosis prediction (Grnarova et al., 2016; Li et al., 2020). However, because of the private nature of medical records, only three large-scale, publicly available medical text datasets are suitable for pretraining models, and real-world, private datasets are often small-scale and imbalanced. As a result, the lack of availability of public datasets is a challenge (Wang et al., 2018). To tackle this problem, we present MeDAL, a large dataset curated for medical abbreviation disambiguation, which can be used for pre-training natural language understanding models. Figure 1 shows an example in the dataset, where the true meaning of the abbreviation 'DHF' is inferred from its context in a medical report about dengue hemorrhagic fever, and Figure 2 shows the pre-training framework. Although this dataset can be used for building abbreviation-expansion systems, it is primarily designed for pre-training. The motivation behind using abbreviation disambiguation as the pre-training task is that abbreviations are widely used and often ambiguous, requiring domain knowledge for understanding. The abbreviation disambiguation task enables models to use domain knowledge to understand the global and local context and the possible meanings of the abbreviation in the medical domain, such as dihydrofolate reductase, dengue hemorrhagic fever, dihydroxyfumarate, and diastolic heart failure. Medical abbreviation disambiguation has been studied (Skreta et al., 2019; Li et al., 2019; Finley et al., 2016; Liu et al., 2018; Joopudi et al., 2018; Jin et al., 2019). In particular, our data generation process is inspired by the reverse substitution technique (Skreta et al., 2019; Finley et al., 2016). Our work differs by proposing transfer learning on other clinical tasks. Existing datasets for medical abbreviation disambiguation, for instance CASI (Moon et al., 2014), are small compared to datasets used for general language model pre-training, and as noted by Li et al. (2019), some are erroneous. Thus, we chose to construct a new dataset for medical abbreviation disambiguation, providing empirical evidence of the benefits of abbreviation pre-training for a wide range of deep learning architectures.

gpt_4o.polished_text:
Recent advancements in mining medical texts have concentrated on developing deep learning models for diverse medical tasks, such as mortality prediction (Grnarova et al., 2016) and diagnosis prediction (Li et al., 2020). However, the inherent privacy of medical records results in a scarcity of large-scale, publicly available datasets suitable for pretraining models, with real-world, private datasets often being small and imbalanced. Consequently, one of the primary challenges in constructing deep learning-based NLP systems for biomedical corpora is the limited availability of public datasets (Wang et al., 2018).

To address this issue, we introduce the Medical Dataset for Abbreviation Disambiguation for Natural Language Understanding (MeDAL), a comprehensive collection of medical texts curated specifically for the task of medical abbreviation disambiguation. This dataset facilitates the pre-training of natural language understanding models. Figure 1 illustrates a sample from the dataset, where the true meaning of the abbreviation "DHF" is deduced from its context, and Figure 2 depicts the pretraining framework. Although MeDAL can be utilized to develop abbreviation-expansion systems, its primary aim is to enable effective pre-training and enhance performance on downstream tasks during fine-tuning.

The rationale for selecting abbreviation disambiguation as the pre-training task is twofold. First, abbreviations are prevalent in medical records and can often be ambiguous (Xu et al., 2007; Islamaj Dogan et al., 2009), posing a challenge for developing deep learning models for medical tasks. Second, comprehending natural language in a knowledge-rich domain like medicine necessitates an understanding of domain-specific knowledge, akin to how humans learn medical text through training. The abbreviation disambiguation task empowers models to employ domain knowledge to interpret both global and local contexts and to discern possible meanings of abbreviations within the medical domain.

The study of medical abbreviation disambiguation has a long history (Skreta et al., 2019; Li et al., 2019; Finley et al., 2016; Liu et al., 2018; Joopudi et al., 2018; Jin et al., 2019), and our research builds upon these foundations. Our data generation process is particularly inspired by the reverse substitution technique (Skreta et al., 2019; Finley et al., 2016). Our approach differs in two major ways: rather than focusing solely on improving abbreviation disambiguation performance, we propose using it as a pre-training task for transfer learning across other clinical tasks. Additionally, existing datasets for medical abbreviation disambiguation, like CASI (Moon et al., 2014), are small compared to those used for general language model pre-training and, as noted by Li et al. (2019), some contain errors. Therefore, we opted to construct a new, sufficiently large dataset for effective pre-training.

Our primary contributions are: presenting a large dataset for pre-training on medical abbreviation disambiguation and providing empirical evidence of the benefits of abbreviation pre-training across various deep learning architectures.

gpt_4o.polished_text:
Drinking water plays a crucial role in flushing out your system, removing unnecessary toxins, and making it easier for you to lose weight. Additionally, water contains no calories, making it a far better choice than sugary beverages that contribute to weight gain. In fact, if you can limit yourself to only consuming water, your chances of shedding those extra pounds will significantly increase. If you crave something with flavor occasionally, opting for unsweetened tea is a good alternative. This should be your go-to beverage choice around the clock, except right before a workout. During that time, you can indulge in a cup of black coffee, or perhaps with a splash of skim milk. The caffeine boost is known to give you an extra kick, helping you to work out a bit harder and more effectively.

Interestingly, drinking water can also boost your metabolism, in addition to making you feel fuller. Recent studies indicate that consuming two glasses of cold water can elevate your metabolism by about 40% for a period of 15 to 20 minutes. Participants in these weight loss studies reportedly lost 15 pounds over a span of three months, primarily by sticking to a regimen of drinking only water. It's important to completely cut out junk food when pursuing more extreme, short-term weight loss goals. While someone following a standard diet might afford to indulge in junk food once or twice without facing drastic consequences, this is not the case for more rigorous weight loss plans. To succeed, you must avoid greasy, fatty foods and those high in sugar content.

Anything battered, fried, coated in chocolate, or preserved with sugar should be off-limits. Take care to read labels, as even foods like yogurt and granola bars can be surprisingly high in sugar. While these are often perceived as healthy options, they may not be as beneficial as you think. Many foods, from pasta to cookies, are rich in simple carbohydrates, which are essentially sugars in disguise. These culprits spike insulin levels, increasing fat storage, and ultimately lead to weight gain. To minimize these effects, cut out processed carbohydrates like white rice, bread, and potatoes, along with cookies, cakes, donuts, chips, pretzels, and ice cream. You might find it beneficial to reduce your overall carbohydrate intake. 

Let's be honest: losing 20 pounds in two weeks is an ambitious goal. To achieve this, you may need to put your body into a state of ketosis, where it burns fat stores instead of glycogen, which have been depleted due to a low or no-carb diet. This means eliminating sweets, starchy vegetables like potatoes, squash, and carrots, whole grains like quinoa and brown rice, and sugary fruits such as bananas, oranges, and apples. Furthermore, feeling hungry can make the temptation to revert to old habits even stronger. Consistently eating healthy, nutritious foods can help curb these cravings and lead to better decision-making when you're full. Whether or not negative-calorie foods actually lead to a calorie deficit remains a topic of debate. The theory suggests that some foods require so much energy to digest that consuming them burns more calories than they contain.

Even if this theory doesn't hold up, you won't gain many calories from eating these foods. When it comes to vegetables, aim to consume more asparagus, beetroot, broccoli, cabbage, cauliflower, celery, cucumber, garlic, green beans, lettuce, onion, radish, spinach, turnip, and zucchini. For fruits, focus on blueberries, cantaloupe, cranberries, grapefruit, honeydew, lemons, limes, oranges, mangoes, papayas, raspberries, strawberries, tomatoes, tangerines, and watermelon. Instead of opting for beef and pork, choose leaner meats like chicken or fish, which are particularly beneficial due to the fatty acids that provide essential oils your body needs. These oils may also help curb the desire for greasy or fatty foods. When it comes to vegetables, incorporate them into every meal—breakfast, lunch, and dinner. They're nutritious, generally low in calories and sugars, and they help keep you full.

In the short term, fad diets can indeed produce results. If you're looking to lose weight rapidly and aren't concerned about regaining it later, a fad diet might be suitable for your situation. However, it's important to understand that these diets are often not healthy and their effects are usually temporary. One of the most popular fad diets currently is juicing, along with the Master Cleanse diet, both of which are liquid-based. These diets can offer quick results, but they are difficult to maintain and not advisable for long-term use. If you're desperate, you might consider them, but it's wise to approach their advice with caution.

gpt_4o.polished_text: Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) (Elman, 1990; Mikolov et al., 2010) are powerful models for handling sequential data. Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) (Hochreiter and Schmidhuber, 1997), a specific RNN architecture, has proven successful in many natural language processing tasks, including language modeling (Józefowicz et al., 2015), dependency parsing (Dyer et al., 2015), sentence compression (Filippova et al., 2015), and machine translation (Sutskever et al., 2014). In natural language processing, it is commonly assumed that LSTMs can capture certain linguistic phenomena. This assumption is primarily supported by evaluating LSTMs in downstream applications. For instance, Bowman et al. (2015) designed two artificial datasets with sentences exhibiting explicit recursive structures. They demonstrated that LSTMs, despite processing input linearly, can implicitly utilize these recursive language structures. Filippova et al. (2015) observed that incorporating explicit syntactic features into LSTMs for sentence compression actually reduced overall system performance. They hypothesized that a basic LSTM is sufficient to capture the syntactic elements beneficial for compression. Understanding which linguistic dimensions are captured by an LSTM is challenging. This difficulty arises because LSTM components compress input sequences into dense vectors, obscuring their role in representing linguistic information. To our knowledge, the only attempt to unravel the reasons behind LSTM performance and limitations is by Karpathy et al. (2015). They employed visualization experiments and cell activation statistics within character-level language modeling. Our work addresses the challenge of interpreting RNN architectures from a linguistic perspective. We introduce the Recurrent Memory Network (RMN), a novel RNN architecture that leverages the strengths of both LSTM and Memory Network (Sukhbaatar et al., 2015). In RMN, the Memory Block component—a variant of Memory Network—accesses recent input words and selectively attends to words relevant for predicting the next word, given the current LSTM state. By analyzing the attention distribution over historical words, RMN enables us to interpret results and uncover underlying dependencies in the data. In this paper, we present the following contributions: RMN has been shown to outperform GRUs in language modeling tasks (Józefowicz et al., 2015). We detail the LSTM architecture used in our work. Notation: Throughout this paper, matrices, vectors, and scalars are denoted by bold uppercase (e.g., W), bold lowercase (e.g., b), and lowercase (e.g., α) letters, respectively. The LSTM used in this work is specified as follows.

gpt_4o.polished_text:
This design utilizes a base color and an accent color to create a visually appealing pattern. The main color is the first listed, while the accent color is the second. For Gryffindor, the colors are Red and Gold; Hufflepuff uses Black and Yellow; Ravenclaw features Blue and Bronze (books) or Blue and Silver (films); and Slytherin employs Green and Silver. The pattern will consist of alternating thick and thin stripes, beginning with a thick stripe in the main color. The main colors are Red for Gryffindor, Yellow for Hufflepuff, Blue for Ravenclaw, and Green for Slytherin.

You can choose between a stockinette stitch, which alternates rows of knits and purls (smooth on one side, bumpy on the other), or a garter stitch, which involves knitting every row for a bumpy texture on both sides. Start by knitting a thick stripe with the main color. Once you reach the end of the row, leave a tail of 4 to 6 inches (10.16 to 15.24 centimeters), cut the yarn, and switch to the accent color. The accent colors are Gold for Gryffindor, Black for Hufflepuff, Bronze or Silver for Ravenclaw, and Silver for Slytherin. Use the same stitch for the accent color, and again leave a 4 to 6-inch tail at the start and end of the row.

This pattern will create the distinctive double-stripe design seen on house scarves in the later films. Most scarves are approximately 60 inches (152.4 centimeters) long. Follow this sequence: 20 rows in the main color, 2 rows in the accent color, 2 rows in the main color, and 2 rows in the accent color. To finish the scarf, knit two stitches onto your right needle, use your left needle to pull the first stitch over the second, and slip it off the right needle. Continue this process until one stitch remains. Cut the yarn to 4 to 6 inches, thread it through the last stitch, and secure it with a tight knot. Use a yarn or tapestry needle to weave the tail into the scarf and trim any excess.

For neat color transitions, tie the tail ends together and weave them into the scarf's body with a yarn or tapestry needle, trimming any extra yarn. To add tassels, wrap yarn around your palm three times, cut the excess, and snip the bottom loop. Use a crochet hook to pull the folded end of the strands through a bottom corner of the scarf, then pull the tail ends through the loop and tighten. Match the tassels to the stripe or alternate between the two house colors, spacing them about 2 stitches apart.

trips_4o.polished_text: Today was one of the saddest days of my life, marked by the heartbreaking farewell to my beloved cousin who had always been a source of joy and love, and whose absence left a void that felt impossible to fill. It started early in the day when the news of her passing reached us, casting a shadow over the morning and setting a somber tone as we prepared for the memorial service and gathered with family to honor her memory. My parents came by to pick me up and take me to the memorial, their presence both a comfort and a painful reminder of the day's gravity, as we leaned on each other for support during this difficult time. Everyone was in a very somber mood, yet the sun shone brightly and the warmth embraced us, creating a strange juxtaposition that seemed to mock our grief, reflecting the internal conflict I felt between the beauty of the day and the sorrow in my heart. We drove out to a church about thirty minutes away, near where my mom grew up, a place rich with family history and memories, which added a layer of poignancy to our gathering, reminding us of the deep roots that connected us all. While driving, I couldn't help but think back to all the good memories I had with my cousin, like the time we built sandcastles at the beach, or when we spent an afternoon baking cookies, her laughter echoing in my mind and filling me with both warmth and sadness. She was always so full of joy, with contagious laughter that brightened every room and left everyone feeling uplifted, her spirit a beacon of light in our family, always bringing us together with her warmth and kindness, and it was hard to comprehend that such a vibrant presence was now gone. But now, that was all gone, and all I had were the memories cascading through my mind, leaving a void in my heart that nothing could fill, an ache that seemed to deepen with each passing moment. Arriving at the church and seeing all of my family, it was hard, with the air heavy with grief and the silence echoing our shared loss, a reminder of the finality we all dreaded and struggled to accept as we faced this painful reality together. It was just so profoundly sad, all of it, an ache that seemed to settle into my very bones, a weight I couldn't shake, as I faced the reality of her absence, feeling the depth of our loss more acutely than ever. Seeing my aunt was the hardest part, I think, because her heartache was palpable, yet I knew that she had a quiet strength that would help her endure and eventually find peace—a strength forged through love, resilience, and the support of her family, which gave me hope for her healing. My uncle, an ordained pastor, helped with the service, and his comforting words seemed to ease some of the pain, like a balm to our aching hearts, reminding us of the hope and faith that still lingered, offering solace in our time of need and showing us the way forward through our sorrow. After the service, we all went to the cemetery and gathered on the hill in the shade, the gentle rustle of leaves offering a moment of solace as we stood together in shared mourning, the unity of our family a source of comfort, reminding us that we were not alone in our grief. Seeing the final resting place really hit me hard, and I started to cry much harder than I had been all day, a release of the sorrow I had been holding back, the reality of her absence crashing down on me like a tidal wave of grief, overwhelming me with the permanence of our loss. All of the memories and the final shock to my brain that she was never coming back made me very sad, and the cool breeze seemed to whisper her absence, making me miss her dearly and feel the depth of our loss, a testament to her impact on our lives and the mark she had left on our hearts. We then all met at a local place for a late lunch and some drinks, the chatter of familiar voices mingling with the clinking of glasses, a bittersweet attempt to find comfort in each other's company, a momentary reprieve from the weight of our sorrow, as we shared stories and laughter in her honor. It was good to see so many of my family, but at the same time, so sad, because I thought that we shouldn't be seeing each other, at least not for this reason, a bittersweet gathering tinged with loss and longing, a reminder of the bond we share despite the circumstances, and the love that connects us even in times of grief. I didn't really know how to feel when we left and I returned home, with the quiet solitude wrapping around me like a blanket, leaving me to ponder the magnitude of what we'd lost, the silence amplifying the void left by her absence, as I tried to come to terms with the new reality. I was deeply saddened and just thought of how my aunt, uncle, and cousins felt, their world forever altered by this loss, and I wished I could do more to ease their pain, my heart aching for their suffering as I hoped for their healing and comfort. I know that life had changed for them forever, and now life was starting again without their dear one, which hurt me again—the permanence of it all settling in my heart like a heavy stone, the reality of moving forward without her a daunting prospect that seemed impossible to bear. But my family is strong, and stronger together, and I know we will get through this like we will any other tragedy that comes our way, united by love and resilience, drawing strength from each other as we navigate the path ahead, our shared memories and love a guiding light in the darkness, helping us find hope and healing in the days to come.

During emotionally charged situations, such as a fight or when feeling hurt, it's easy to make declarative statements like "You are a liar and you hurt my feelings." However, psychologists advise that using "I" statements is more effective and reduces tension. An "I" statement frames your feelings as personal experiences rather than accusations against your partner. A well-structured "I" statement includes three components: an expression of emotion ("I feel _____"), a fair and unemotional description of the behavior causing the feeling ("I feel _____ when you ______"), and an explanation of why the behavior affects you ("I feel ____ when you _____, because it _________"). 

If your relationship is relatively new or you are inexperienced in sharing your feelings, it's wise to take things slowly. Continue working on communication daily, and have an open discussion with your partner about your comfort level with sharing personal thoughts and feelings. Establish a timeline that allows both of you to gradually become more open with one another. Avoid rushing into deep or difficult conversations, and let them occur naturally when both parties are ready. Don't pressure your partner or allow her to pressure you; move at a pace that feels comfortable for both of you. Improving communication, even incrementally, will ultimately strengthen your relationship. Self-disclosure statements can be particularly useful, especially if you're not accustomed to sharing your feelings or discussing deeply personal topics. They allow you to gradually reveal yourself to your partner, with the expectation that she will reciprocate. Consider using self-disclosing prompts like "I am a person who ____," "One thing I wish people knew about me is _____," or "When I try to express intimate feelings, _____" to initiate these conversations.

trips_4o.polished_text: This paper introduces LatinCy, a set of trained general-purpose Latin-language "core" pipelines. These pipelines are designed for use with the spaCy natural language processing framework (Honnibal and Montani, 2023). These pipelines process Latin text from start to finish, handling key NLP tasks such as sentence segmentation, word tokenization, lemmatization, part-of-speech and morphological tagging, dependency parsing, and named entity recognition (NER). Three models have been trained so far, adhering to spaCy conventions: la_core_web_sm, la_core_web_md, and la_core_web_lg. Here, 'la' signifies the Latin language, 'core' denotes a pipeline with all the components including NER, and 'web' refers to training data mainly from Universal Dependency treebanks. 'Sm', 'md', and 'lg' indicate the model sizes—small, medium, or large—with 'md' and 'lg' incorporating subword vectors for vocabulary, unlike 'sm'. The default pipeline features spaCy components like 'tagger', 'morphologizer', and 'trainable_lemmatizer' (EditTreeLemmatizer, Müller et al., 2015), along with 'parser' and 'ner'. Sentence segmentation is part of the dependency parsing task, and it includes orthographical regularization components that allow the 'trainable_lemmatizer' to use norm_ as a fallback instead of text. The -que enclitic is split by customizing the spaCy tokenizer, except for exceptions such as neque, atque, quoque, etc., which are listed in que_exceptions in scripts/functions.py. All components share the 'tok2vec' listener during training, except 'ner', which has a separate listener. Contributions to annotations were made by Nora Bernhardt (ner), Tim Geelhaar (tagger, morphologizer, parser, ner), and Vincent Koch (ner).

gpt_4o.polished_text: This paper presents LatinCy, a set of Latin-language "core" pipelines for the spaCy NLP framework. These pipelines process plaintext Latin for tasks like sentence segmentation, tokenization, lemmatization, POS tagging, and more. Three models have been developed: la_core_web_sm, la_core_web_md, and la_core_web_lg. The language code 'la' stands for Latin, and 'core' indicates a full-feature pipeline, including NER. Floret vectors for 'md' and 'lg' models are trained and integrated during initialization for further training. The motivation for this pipeline includes: 1) being the first end-to-end Latin pipelines in spaCy, expanding NLP resources for Latin researchers; 2) leveraging Universal Dependencies treebank annotations, synthesizing five treebanks into a unified dataset with 54,000 sentences; 3) allowing accuracy metrics for components, enhancing error analysis, especially for morphological tagging and dependency parsing.

trips_4o.polished_text: The field of natural language processing (NLP) has been marked by impressive advancements and breakthroughs in recent years, leading to significant improvements across various applications. The appearance of new model architectures, including the emergence of generative transformers, has brought along with it widespread usage and attention. Pre-trained language models (PLMs) have also gained significant focus due to their transformative capabilities. Still, most of these models were trained on large amounts of web content, and while they excel at tasks in a general-purpose setting, there is still a noticeable performance gap when it comes to tackling domain-specific challenges, particularly in specialized areas. One of these challenging domains is biomedicine, which centers around the intricate study of the human body, diseases, drugs, and various treatments that aim to improve health outcomes. Biomedical text is often characterized as highly complex because of its advanced terminology, which frequently includes names of chemical compounds, long-spanning relations, and other jargon not commonly used. This specialized language poses challenges for NLP models trained on general corpora. For NLP models trained on general corpora to work well in the biomedical domain, researchers have turned to transfer learning methods and domain adaptation, aiming to bridge the performance gap in specialized tasks. The most common approach to domain adaptation is to continue the initial general pre-training of language models with data sourced from domain-specific medical corpora, allowing the models to gain more relevant insights into the field. Examples of models adapted in this way are BioBERT (Lee et al., 2019) and SciBERT (Beltagy et al., 2019). These models drew the additional training data from biomedical and computer science research abstracts to enhance their performance. Dropping the mixed-domain approach from previous frameworks, models like PubMedBERT (Gu et al., 2020) and BioLinkBERT (Yasunaga et al., 2022) were instead trained solely on PubMed research articles, with BioLinkBERT even leveraging links (citations) to other research articles to enhance its contextual understanding. While domain fine-tuning of whole PLMs has proven to increase the performance on downstream biomedical NLP tasks, additional pre-training can often be resource-intensive and infeasible for smaller research groups. In situations where computing power is limited, a promising research direction has emerged. This promising research direction has emerged in the form of knowledge-enhanced language models (KELMs) (Hu et al., 2023), which integrate external knowledge sources to augment model capabilities. It refers to any set of methods that try to incorporate external knowledge into language models, usually by injecting it into the model’s input, architecture, or output. This integration process is known as knowledge enhancement, and it significantly boosts model performance. In a sea of knowledge-enhancement methods, an especially interesting one is the utilization of adapters, which provide a lightweight and efficient way to adapt large language models to new tasks and domains. Broadly speaking, adapters are small bottleneck feed-forward layers that are inserted within each layer of a transformer-based language model (Houlsby et al., 2019; Pfeiffer et al., 2020b), allowing for efficient task-specific training. The small amount of additional parameters allows for the injection of new data or knowledge without requiring the whole model to be fine-tuned, thus saving resources and time. Adapters plugged on top of large language models will often only have around 1% of the number of training parameters compared to the transformer, making them a cost-effective solution for researchers. The transformer model’s learned parameters (weights) are frozen and left unchanged, and only the adapter is fine-tuned to adapt the model to new tasks or domains. Other than being lightweight on resources, this approach also helps avoid the problem of catastrophic forgetting, where language models forget their existing knowledge from the pre-training corpora when they are fine-tuned on a new, smaller corpus (Colon-Hernandez et al., 2021). This paper specifically focuses on using adapters to inject structured biomedical knowledge from large knowledge graphs into PLMs, aiming to improve their performance on specialized tasks. We provide an overview of existing adapter approaches for the biomedical domain, as well as existing biomedical language models, offering insight into their design and application. We perform extensive experiments to test the performance of knowledge-enhanced, adapter-based biomedical language models on a number of representative biomedical classification tasks, including document classification, question answering, and natural language inference. We show that the model performance is improved in several instances on downstream tasks and provide a deeper look into the resulting change in model predictions, offering a comprehensive analysis of the enhancements. Finally, our experiments demonstrate that the OntoChem ontology (Irmer et al., 2013), which has not been used for knowledge enhancement yet, is a viable alternative to other prominent knowledge sources, providing new opportunities for future research and application.

gpt_4o.polished_text: The field of natural language processing (NLP) has witnessed remarkable progress and innovation in recent years. This advancement is largely due to the introduction of novel model architectures, such as generative transformers and pre-trained language models (PLMs). These developments have led to widespread adoption and significant attention within the NLP community. However, despite their success in general-purpose tasks, most models face challenges with domain-specific applications. A particularly demanding domain is biomedicine, which involves the study of human physiology, diseases, pharmaceuticals, and therapeutic interventions. Text in the biomedical field is often intricate, containing specialized terminology, names of chemical compounds, and complex relationships. These elements frequently include jargon that is not commonly encountered in everyday language usage. To address the performance gap in biomedical NLP tasks, researchers have explored transfer learning and domain adaptation techniques. The predominant strategy involves continuing the pre-training of language models using domain-specific medical data. Notable examples include BioBERT and SciBERT, which were further trained on biomedical and computer science research abstracts. Moving away from mixed-domain data, models like PubMedBERT and BioLinkBERT were trained exclusively on PubMed research articles. BioLinkBERT also utilized citation links to augment its training data with additional scholarly articles. Although domain-specific fine-tuning of PLMs enhances performance in biomedical tasks, additional pre-training is often resource-intensive. This requirement can be challenging for smaller research groups and in situations with constrained computing resources. A promising research avenue has emerged through knowledge-enhanced language models (KELMs). This approach involves integrating external knowledge into language models, either within the input, architecture, or output. Among the various knowledge-enhancement strategies, adapters have garnered particular interest. Adapters are essentially small bottleneck feed-forward layers inserted within each layer of a transformer-based model. These additional parameters enable the introduction of new data or knowledge without necessitating the fine-tuning of the entire model. This modular approach means adapters typically contain only about 1% of the total parameters compared to the transformer model. By freezing the transformer's learned parameters, only the adapter layers undergo fine-tuning. This method is not only resource-efficient but also mitigates the issue of catastrophic forgetting, where models lose previously acquired knowledge during new corpus training. Our paper specifically investigates the use of adapters to incorporate structured biomedical knowledge from knowledge graphs into PLMs. We provide a comprehensive overview of existing adapter methodologies and biomedical language models. Our research includes extensive experiments to evaluate the performance of knowledge-enhanced, adapter-based models on various biomedical classification tasks. These tasks include document classification, question answering, and natural language inference. Our results demonstrate improved model performance on several downstream tasks and offer insights into changes in model predictions. Additionally, our findings highlight the OntoChem ontology as a viable alternative to other prominent knowledge sources, showcasing its potential for knowledge enhancement in NLP models.

gpt_4o.polished_text:
Before selling an item, it's crucial to gather some basic information about it, such as its style, material, and, if possible, the maker. For example, if you're selling your grandparents' old dining room table, you can find relevant details in general reference books on antiques, which are usually available at libraries. Once you identify the item and its approximate value, determining a fair price becomes easier.

Start by looking for similar items on the market. Compare their condition to yours, noting any differences in style, material, or maker. Check the prices set by dealers and consider talking to them about their pricing rationale. However, be cautious: never let a dealer appraise an item you might sell to them, as this poses a conflict of interest. If a dealer values your item and then offers to buy it, it's best to decline.

Online platforms like eBay, Amazon, and Craigslist are excellent resources for checking what people are willing to pay for similar items. On eBay, you can search for recently sold items to see actual sale prices. Keep in mind that these competitive sites often feature lower prices, so they may not provide the best indication if you're aiming for maximum profit. For comprehensive pricing information, consider using price guides like Kovel’s, known for antiques and collectibles. They offer both free and premium subscriptions.

Appraisers can provide various price estimates depending on your selling intentions:

1. **Auction Value**: This is the expected selling price at an auction. Rare or valuable items often do well at auctions, while less rare items typically fetch lower prices than retail due to limited demand.

2. **Retail Value**: This is the price your item might sell for in an antique store. If your item isn't rare, the retail value might be higher than the auction value. However, remember that dealers won't buy at full retail value, as they need to make a profit.

3. **Insurance Value**: If you choose not to sell, an appraiser can determine this value, reflecting the replacement cost if the item is destroyed or stolen. This is particularly useful for especially valuable items.

Many believe that cleaning or restoring an item will increase its value, but altering it without consulting an expert can significantly lower its worth. It's best to keep the item in its original condition, flaws and all.

trips_4o.polished_text: A contract is a legally binding agreement between two or more parties, detailing the obligations, rights, and responsibilities of each party involved. Modern organizations maintain a large inventory of contracts and other legal documents, including purchase agreements, employment contracts, and confidentiality agreements. A typical large Fortune 500 organization manages 40,000 active contracts at any given time (Pery and Simon 2019). Reviewing these contracts manually involves significant time and cost, often requiring thousands of staff hours and substantial financial resources, which can be a substantial burden for firms. Conducting due diligence and risk analysis on them is also time-consuming, requiring careful examination of each clause and provision to identify potential risks and ensure compliance with legal standards. However, due to the large scale and ever-increasing volume of contracts, manually segregating paragraphs to derive actionable information poses a challenging task for any law firm or legal department. Therefore, automatic categorization and classification of legal clauses and provisions using natural language processing and artificial intelligence has been of academic as well as commercial interest (Katz et al. 2023, DALE 2019). The primary research interest of this paper is the classification of provisions into topics. This requires two crucial considerations. A) Sophisticated neural network classification methods require a large set of labeled curated data, which can be a difficult and costly exercise. B) The classifier models trained on a general language corpus are not efficient for the legal classification task because legal texts have a specialized language and distinctive vocabulary with peculiar expressions and terms that do not commonly occur in day-to-day spoken or written language. The focus of this research is the usage of transfer learning (Zhuang et al. 2019) techniques because they look promising to address the two challenges. The central tenet of these techniques is to first train a general-purpose language model as a base model on a very large general corpus, without using any task-specific labeled dataset. At this step, the base model encodes the semantic information as lower-order features. Then, fine-tune (Dodge et al. 2020) this foundational model for the classification task using relatively few labeled data points and the weights learned in the base model. By following this approach, higher-order feature representations are fine-tuned, making them more efficient at the specific task. This is achieved by utilizing the lower-order general features learned in the original base model without having to explicitly re-create them. This avoids the need to re-train a large model using a large dataset for the specific task. The aim of this research is to examine the applicability of fine-tuning a pre-trained large language model for the classification task. In support of this, the main topic of a contract will be predicted. The corpus of contracts used is obtained from public domain filings in the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). It is curated in Legal General Language Understanding Evaluation (LexGLUE) (Chalkidis et al. 2021), which uses the LEDGAR dataset (Tuggener et al. 2020). Each label in the dataset represents the single most important topic (subject) in the contract provision (refer Table 1 for sample data format). The provisions and their count are given in appendix Table A.

gpt_4o.polished_text:
A contract is a legally binding agreement between two or more parties that outlines the terms of the agreement. Modern organizations manage a vast inventory of contracts and other legal documents. A typical large Fortune organization handles up to 40,000 active contracts at any given time (Pery and Simon 2019). Reviewing and analyzing these contracts manually for due diligence and risk analysis is time-consuming and costly. According to a study (Dodd 2018), over 50% of contract review tasks, such as clause identification and classification (Zhao 2019), are repetitive and require specialized legal knowledge. However, the sheer volume of contracts makes manual segregation of paragraphs to extract actionable information a daunting task for any law firm or legal department. Consequently, automatic categorization and classification of legal clauses using natural language processing and artificial intelligence have garnered significant academic and commercial interest (Katz et al. 2023, DALE 2019).

This paper primarily focuses on classifying contract provisions into topics. Two key challenges are considered: A) Sophisticated neural network classification methods demand a large, labeled, and curated dataset, which can be difficult and costly to obtain. B) Classifier models trained on general language corpora are inefficient for legal classification tasks due to the specialized language and unique vocabulary of legal texts. This research explores the use of transfer learning (Zhuang et al. 2019) techniques to address these challenges. The central idea is to initially train a general-purpose language model on a large corpus without task-specific labeled data. This base model encodes semantic information as lower-order features. It is then fine-tuned (Dodge et al. 2020) for the classification task using fewer labeled data points and the learned weights from the base model. This approach enhances higher-order feature representations, making them more effective for specific tasks by leveraging the general features learned in the base model, thus avoiding the need for extensive retraining.

The aim of this research is to explore the feasibility of fine-tuning a pre-trained large language model for legal domain classification. The primary goal is to predict the main topic of a provision in a contract. The contract corpus is sourced from public domain filings in the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and curated in the Legal General Language Understanding Evaluation (LexGLUE) (Chalkidis et al. 2021) using the LEDGAR dataset (Tuggener et al. 2020). Each label in the dataset represents the most important topic in the corresponding contract provision (refer to Table 1 for sample data format). The provisions and their counts are provided in Appendix Table A.

trips_4o.polished_text: While information and communication technology is essential for many to thrive, 6 billion people still do not have access to broadband, 4 billion do not have access to the Internet, and 2 billion do not have access to a mobile phone (Zelezny-Green et al., 2018). Latest estimates from the UNESCO Institute for Statistics (2023) indicate that around 213 million adults (over 15 years old) could not read or write in 2022 across the sub-Saharan African region, including nearly 49 million young people (15-24 years old). In Senegal, ANSD (2021) reports an overall illiteracy rate of 48.2%, which was 62.7% in rural areas. The literacy rate in countries is often influenced by their official language. In Senegal, the official language is French but is rarely used by the population in their daily lives. Senegalese people primarily use their native languages or Wolof as a main language of communication. World Bank (2021) reports that nearly 65% of Senegalese who do not use the Internet are impacted by a lack of digital literacy. This is partly due to the limited, if at all, availability of content in the language they speak. Currently, there is a significant lack of accessible content for those who do not speak the official languages in Africa. The development of technologies and tools for the most widely spoken languages would allow a greater number of the Senegalese people to use smartphones and applications, and access content that is still unavailable today. Research work including Medhi et al. (2011) and the success of WhatsApp voice communication show that the development of conversational voice services in local languages is a credible and promising way of making services more accessible. Aker (2011) also suggested at the time that combining a voice-based approach with information that can be accessed through answers to common farmer questions would overcome literacy challenges associated with the common texting modes. To make progress in this area, robust speech recognition systems must be developed for these languages. While automatic speech recognition (ASR) technologies are well-established in the languages most commonly found on the Web, there are still extremely limited solutions dedicated to African languages. In Senegal, Wolof, Sereer, Pulaar, Joola, Malinké, and Soninké languages are designated as national languages in the Constitution, but none of these six languages seriously benefit from the major technological advances generated by AI. However, Wolof, Pulaar, and Sereer languages are spoken among more than two-thirds of the Senegalese population (Leclerc, 2023). Agriculture is the primary source of income for 2 billion people around the world (Zelezny-Green et al., 2018). In Senegal, 55% of the population participates in the agricultural value chain, including family farming, livestock breeding, and fishing. Today, digital technologies are assisting farmers in expanding their businesses by enabling them to position themselves on marketplaces, providing them with information on commodity prices, and granting them access to suitable financial services. Nonetheless, such solutions are still not appropriate for farmers, mainly because of the prevalence of written communication and the use of a language they do not speak when interacting with these interfaces. With the intention of creating speech solutions, this dataset is designed to address the need in this area. This paper contributes in the dataset created from speech data produced and annotated during the Kallaama project, as well as textual data gathered from the web, with the aim of developing voice-based solutions in local languages. In Senegal, ANSD (2021) reports an overall illiteracy rate of 48.2%, rising to 62.7% in rural areas. Literacy rates are tied to a country's official language. In Senegal, French is the official language but is rarely used by the population in daily life. Instead, Senegalese people primarily communicate using their native languages or Wolof as a lingua franca. The World Bank (2021) reports that nearly 65% of Senegalese who do not use the Internet are hindered by a lack of digital literacy, partly due to the limited availability of content in their spoken languages. There is currently a significant shortage of accessible content for those who do not speak Africa's official languages. Developing technologies and tools for the most widely spoken languages would enable more Senegalese people to use smartphones and applications and access content currently unavailable. Research by Medhi et al. (2011) and the success of WhatsApp voice communication demonstrate that developing conversational voice services in local languages is a promising way to make services more accessible. Aker (2011) also suggested that combining a voice-based approach with information accessible through answers to common farmer questions would overcome literacy challenges posed by text-based communication. To advance in this area, robust speech recognition systems must be designed for these languages. While automatic speech recognition (ASR) technologies are mature in languages commonly found on the Web, there are still very few solutions dedicated to African languages. In Senegal, Wolof, Sereer, Pulaar, Joola, Malinké, and Soninké are recognized as national languages in the Constitution, but none of these six languages seriously benefit from the major technological advances generated by AI. trips_4o.polished_text: About six months ago, I went to the eye doctor. I needed to get my eyes checked. My eyes were getting tired quickly, and I was experiencing frequent mild headaches due to eyestrain, which were becoming increasingly severe. The doctor did a thorough examination and immediately noticed how misaligned my eyes were. He referred me to a surgeon to get my eyes aligned. I have had misaligned eyes for almost half a century. I had never considered surgery because my older sister had undergone surgery for her misaligned eyes and is now practically blind in one eye. I chose to live with my condition. Upon reaching adulthood, I spent a year in vision therapy to try to correct the problem. Vision therapy did help, but over time my eyes reverted and turned inward significantly. The doctor explained to me that my condition is different from my sister's and that surgery would not cause me to lose vision. My sister had another condition that caused her to shut one eye off completely. He indicated that at my age, surgery was the only viable solution. So, I scheduled an appointment with a surgeon for an evaluation. The evaluation involved the surgeon placing various prisms in front of my left eye, which immediately caused me to see double. The surgeon worked with me for several minutes, helping my eyes adjust. My left eye turned inward 70–80 points and could only be corrected to 40 points without causing double vision. It was decided that surgery on my right eye would also be beneficial, allowing for at least a 50-point correction. I discussed the situation with my husband, who thought it was a good idea to have the surgery. However, the surgery scheduler contacted me three months later, informing me that I would need a new evaluation before the surgery. I told her that if this was the case, I was not interested because we had already paid $600 for the first evaluation. She consulted with the surgeon, who confirmed that a second evaluation was unnecessary, and the surgery was scheduled for August. Three weeks ago, my husband took me to the eye hospital, where I underwent surgery on both of my eyes. I cannot believe how having mostly aligned eyes has changed my life! My crossed eyes always prompted people to look at me strangely. Some companies have been hesitant to hire me, thinking there was something physically wrong with me. Children always stared at me, often asking why my eyes were so crossed, but this issue is no longer a concern for me. Just last week, I went to the grocery store and was amazed at how much more respectfully I was treated. It is also wonderful to wake up in the morning and have almost perfectly aligned eyes. When looking in the mirror, I feel more confident while getting ready for the day.

trips_4o.polished_text: Four months ago, I had to part with my most beloved possession, my faithful yellow 1971 Chevy Corvette, because I lost my job and needed to save my family home from foreclosure until things improved. Since I was seven, I dreamed about this car while looking at car magazines with my school buddies. One day, I came home from school and told my mom and dad that someday this car would be mine. They, being simple country folk living in rural Texas, laughed at my naive childhood dreams. My father, a strict military man stationed at Fort Hood army base, was certainly not interested in fast cars or any 'fancy' things like that. He would say that such things were a 'foolish waste of time and money.' In contrast, I was a free spirit, quite different from my parents and their ways. When I turned twenty-two, I followed my dream of owning a 'super car' and purchased my Corvette with my own hard-earned money. I loved my car all these years, not as a fancy object to show off, but as a symbol of my hard work and dreams. It was a reflection of my personality and values, embodying my character. Together, we went through many memorable experiences in life, each of which added a new chapter to my story. Although it was a very tough and heartbreaking decision, I had to sell it for my wife and my two children. Their well-being and comfort are much more important to me than any sentimental object, even my 'super car.' I told myself that when things turned around, I would always be able to get another one. While cars can be easily replaced, a family's happiness is a once-in-a-lifetime experience. My heart broke when I took it out of the garage for the last time and handed the keys to a young man who had come all the way from Salt Lake City, Utah, with his father to purchase it. I looked at his face and saw his eyes shining with excitement. He reminded me of myself when I first got my car, a dreamer who reached his goal! I wished him good luck and hoped he would enjoy it as much as I did all these years.

gpt_4o.polished_text: Sign languages serve as the primary means of communication for approximately 70 million deaf individuals worldwide. These languages utilize the visual-gestural modality to convey meaning through manual articulations combined with non-manual elements such as facial expressions and body movements. Sign language processing (SLP) is a specialized subfield of natural language processing (NLP) that intertwines with computer vision and sign language linguistics to advance research and understanding. This field encompasses tasks such as sign language recognition, translation, and production, as documented by various researchers in recent years. A typical dataset supporting SLP research includes spoken language text, sign language glosses, and accompanying videos, which are crucial for understanding. Examples of such datasets include RWTH-PHOENIXWeather 2014T for German Sign Language and CSL-Daily for Chinese Sign Language, both of which have been introduced by respective researchers over the years. However, significant advancements in specific tasks, datasets, or languages are often limited and not easily transferable to broader, more challenging settings. This limitation is primarily due to the small, domain-specific vocabulary and constrained data size found in many existing datasets. Recent developments have seen the emergence of sign language corpora with thousands of signing hours for high-resource sign languages. Examples include BOBSL for British Sign Language and YouTube-ASL for American Sign Language, which offer much larger datasets for research. Meanwhile, outside the realm of SLP, there has been tremendous progress in deep pretrained models across different modalities, such as GPT for text, masked autoencoders for images, and wav2vec 2.0 for speech. These models are typically pretrained on vast amounts of data, often with minimal supervision, but they exhibit remarkable multilingual and multi-task capabilities. The visual nature of sign languages, with their larger lexical similarity due to iconicity and smaller grammatical variation compared to spoken languages, potentially facilitates easier transfer between different sign languages. This is in contrast to the challenges faced with text in various spoken languages, which often encounter tokenization and out-of-vocabulary errors. However, unlike discrete text tokens, the dense continuous video signals associated with sign languages are computationally expensive to process and pose significant challenges for self-supervised training approaches. Given that SLP tasks and datasets typically involve both text and visual/signed modalities, researchers have drawn inspiration from models like OpenAI’s CLIP to connect text with sign language videos. For video understanding, subsequent work such as VideoCLIP has primarily focused on tasks including action recognition and video question answering. Nonetheless, existing multimodal models such as CLIP and VideoCLIP understand visual content at a coarse-grained level and within generic domains, failing to address the complexities inherent in sign language. This research demonstrates the deficiency of contemporary AI models in comprehending sign language both intuitively and empirically. The current work utilizes sign-language-specific data to train a CLIP-like model tailored for SLP purposes. Initially, the feasibility of this approach is validated through a model named FingerCLIP, which successfully comprehends the fingerspelling of individual letters. Following this, a large-scale pretraining dataset is curated using the Spreadthesign dictionary, encompassing approximately 500 hours of signing. This dataset serves as a foundation for comprehensive pretraining, fine-tuning, and evaluation on full-fledged sign languages.

trips_4o.polished_text: Recent advancements in Large Language Models (LLMs) [1]–[7] demonstrate their remarkable capabilities, such as processing and generating human-like text, with applications spanning domains like content creation, customer service, and personalized education. These advanced computational models have revolutionized various domains, including robotics, where LLMs are increasingly employed to bridge the communication gap between humans and machines by executing tasks based on complex human instructions and improving human-robot interaction. This allows robots to execute tasks such as sorting objects, navigating environments, and engaging in conversational interactions, enhancing the efficiency and adaptability of robotics systems through the use of LLMs. However, as LLMs are widely used in robotics applications, challenges arise in accurately interpreting humans' natural language commands, such as dealing with ambiguous instructions, understanding personal preferences, and ensuring consistent communication. Our research is motivated by growing concerns about hallucination and inconsistency in LLMs as reported in recent literature [8]–[10], which impact the reliability and safety of robotic systems. Hallucination refers to generating false or misleading information that doesn’t accurately reflect the input provided, often caused by overfitting or lack of contextual understanding, leading to potential errors in robotics applications. This is particularly problematic in robotic applications, as LLMs can misinterpret humans’ instructions or generate unsafe commands when they hallucinate, ultimately increasing the risk of accidents or injuries and impeding the applicability of LLM-integrated systems. Additionally, inconsistency, which refers to the phenomenon of LLMs producing different responses to the same query, presents challenges for maintaining reliable human-robot communication. The work was supported by funding from King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST), and the SDAIA-KAUST Center of Excellence in Data Science and Artificial Intelligence (SDAIA-KAUST AI). Abugurain and Park are affiliated with the Electrical and Computer Engineering Program, Computer, Electrical, and Mathematical Science and Engineering Division, King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST). These issues limit the functional scope of robots and raise concerns about safety, especially in environments where human-robot interaction is frequent, highlighting the importance of addressing these challenges to ensure effective and secure robotics applications. In this work, we address these limitations by enhancing the reliability of LLMs for robot motion planning and execution through a robust framework. We propose a framework that effectively detects and corrects misinterpretation and inconsistencies, thereby bridging the gap between the potential of LLMs and their practical, reliable application in robotics. Our framework, which can be integrated into existing robotic systems using LLMs, minimizes ambiguity in human natural language instructions, enabling robots to understand and execute the instructions with improved reliability. This is challenging because human natural language is inherently ambiguous, where meanings are frequently implied rather than explicitly stated, necessitating a nuanced understanding of human communication. For instance, given an instruction “Go to the room where I forgot my keys,” the robot must understand the context of where the user forgot their keys to plan and execute the navigation command. Furthermore, the robot needs to determine whether a given human instruction contains all the information about their preferences required to execute the instructed task, emphasizing the importance of understanding user preferences. To illustrate, consider an instruction “Go to the room I like the most.” The instruction appears unambiguous as there is exactly one room the user likes the most, but it does not indicate which room they like the most, presenting a challenge in understanding the user's specific intention. In this example, the robot must detect that the instruction is incomplete and ask the user for more information about their preference, utilizing a detection mechanism to ensure clarity. Drawing from these two examples, we consider ambiguity as the uncertainty in a sentence’s meaning that allows for multiple, equally probable interpretations, highlighting its importance in understanding human language instructions. Instructions with unspecified preferences, though not ambiguous, are regarded as incomplete, necessitating additional information on the preferences to complete the task effectively. This paper posits that ambiguity is a universal phenomenon, not specific to any particular user, while preference is user-specific, underscoring the need for tailored interaction. As our main contributions, we develop a framework capable of resolving ambiguities in natural language instructions and clarifying them through meaningful queries to enhance communication. Additionally, it can detect whether the instructions contain all the necessary information regarding user preferences, query the users whenever additional details are required to complete the task, and also retain this information for future use. The rest of the paper is organized as follows: We present the background and related work in Section II, discuss the problem formulation and proposed framework in Section III, validate the efficacy of our framework through experiments in Section IV, and conclude the paper with summaries and discussions in Section V, providing comprehensive insights into our research findings.

gpt_4o.polished_text:
Large-scale pre-training of language models has emerged as the standard approach for numerous tasks in natural language processing. Additionally, recent research indicates that models pre-trained with massive datasets of code can also perform competitively on various tasks, such as code generation and classification. These coding tasks share similarities with natural language (NL) tasks in terms of their problem formulation, which is why leveraging language model architectures initially designed for NL has become a common practice. The design principles underpinning these neural language models differ significantly from those of classic rule-based program generation systems. Specifically, while neural language models treat programs as sequences of tokens, traditional program generation systems utilize language grammar and code structure.

Despite the advanced performance of pre-trained language models on code understanding tasks, it remains unclear what these models have internalized from the code corpus. In this work, we aim to investigate whether large-scale pre-training is sufficient for effective code representation learning. To this end, we conduct a pioneering systematic study to analyze how pre-trained language models comprehend the syntactic structures inherent in programming languages. We introduce CodeSyntax, a comprehensive benchmark comprising programs annotated with syntactic relationships between different tokens. These syntactic relationships are derived from the edges present in the abstract syntax trees (AST) of the programs, as shown in some examples in Figure 1.

These syntactic relations exhibit functional similarities to dependency relations in NL, where prior research has demonstrated that attention heads in pre-trained language models can help identify NL relation types (Clark et al., 2019; Raganato et al., 2018). To evaluate how well pre-trained language models capture the syntactic structures in code, we adapt this approach for the programming language (PL) domain. Our experiments focus on investigating the zero-shot capability of existing pre-training methods, evaluating these models without fine-tuning them on our benchmark.

We assess state-of-the-art pre-trained language models for code representation learning, including CuBERT (Kanade et al., 2020) and CodeBERT (Feng et al., 2020). These models share a common characteristic: they utilize the same Transformer-based architecture as NL models (Vaswani et al., 2017; Devlin et al., 2019), allowing us to directly compare their performance in capturing syntactic structures. Figure 2 provides a preview of our key findings.

Our primary observation indicates that pre-training alone is insufficient for learning the syntactic relations present in code. Surprisingly, models pre-trained on code do not consistently outperform models pre-trained solely on NL corpora. For example, RoBERTa, which is not trained on code but shares an identical model architecture, achieves better performance than CodeBERT, which is trained on both text and code corpora. This suggests that pre-training on programs as token sequences does not aid in learning syntactic relations. In contrast, pre-training without dependency relations still enables language models to understand NL syntax to a certain degree.

Moreover, for understanding code syntax, pre-trained models perform worse than simple baselines that select tokens using a fixed positional offset. For instance, always choosing the (p+2)-th token as the p-th token’s dependency yields higher accuracy than any attention head for several relation types. Conversely, the same model architectures pre-trained on text corpora achieve decent accuracy in identifying dependency relations within the NL domain, where simple baselines perform significantly worse.

Our analysis reveals several key differences between NL and PL that impact the syntactic understanding capabilities of pre-trained models. Firstly, programs are more structured than NL sentences, often containing hierarchical structures that embody long-term dependencies between code tokens. Consequently, many syntactic relation types in programs are located between distant tokens, making them difficult for attention heads to recognize. In contrast, dependency relations in NL sentences typically connect nearby token pairs, allowing attention heads to more effectively identify the correct relations.

Language models are adept at recognizing keyword-based relations, such as matching an else keyword with its corresponding if token. Interestingly, the inclusion of tokens like newlines and semicolons significantly impacts performance in the code domain. These findings suggest that existing pre-trained models exhibit differing performance in PL and NL domains regarding syntactic understanding. As such, directly applying training paradigms developed for NL could be suboptimal for program learning, prompting us to consider designing better approaches for modeling code structure in future work.

The CodeSyntax benchmark has been constructed to evaluate language models' performance in understanding code syntax, focusing specifically on Python and Java languages. Publicly released model checkpoints for both CuBERT (Kanade et al., 2020) and CodeBERT (Feng et al., 2020) are pre-trained on these languages. We obtain code samples from CodeSearchNet (Husain et al., 2019), a large-scale dataset encompassing code from various programming languages, to support our evaluation efforts.
