trips_4o.polished_text: The creation and use of visualizations are common in many areas of science. They are also prevalent in practice. The field of legal visualization has a long tradition of using visuals to clarify complex legal relationships and scenarios. The core advantage of visualization is its ability to graphically represent complex information, serving as a form of complexity reduction that enhances human comprehension. This can include large data sets that are easier for humans to understand visually, as certain data properties can only be discovered through visual means. Examples range from visual representations of business data used in statistics and data analytics to visualizations of medical data for discovering features in the human body, and visualizations of sensor data can be extrapolated to create animated weather maps. Visualization also includes visual representations of knowledge to facilitate human communication, such as in educational settings or complex project presentations, which, unlike data visualizations typically generated by algorithms, are created and curated manually by humans. Depending on the visualization's purpose, they may use formal or semi-formal languages common in conceptual modeling or consist of ad-hoc shapes and drawings, as found in infographics or structural legal visualizations, requiring a deep understanding of the domain and scenario, along with the skills to use the right tools and procedures. These tools range from drawing tools for creating arbitrary shapes or reusing existing ones to modeling tools that use predefined shapes and concepts, with more sophisticated tools existing for creating 3D representations, while standard drawing tools are user-friendly, modeling and specialized visualization tools often require significant training. The recent emergence of advanced large language models offers new ways to address this challenge, especially through coding in various languages. Large language models are trained on vast amounts of text, forming a probabilistic model of word sequences, with each word in the model's vocabulary assigned a probability based on given or generated sequences, and advances in science and technology have increased these models' training sets to hundreds of billions of parameters. In November 2022, OpenAI released a large language model as a dialogue system called ChatGPT, along with an API. The GPT language models are trained on over 175 billion parameters and can generate text in various styles and output programming code, and they may soon be able to process multimodal data, such as images. Recently, the application of these models has been explored in various domains to support text and code creation. We report on experiments using GPT-4 to create visualizations through prompts, exploring the potential for generating visualizations, particularly for structural legal visualizations in legal informatics. We seek to contribute to the discussion on how AI can support visualizations from a metaperspective, aiming to generate visualizations based on graphical primitives, such as vector graphics or programming code, contrasting with other approaches using models like DALL-E for pixel graphics. The experiments are structured into categories: two-dimensional visualizations and simple and complex three-dimensional visualizations for web environments and 3D modeling editors, with the first category focusing on structural legal visualizations typically created manually today, such as those made in PowerPoint. The second and third categories target real 3D visualizations, often created with programming libraries like three.js or Blender, requiring advanced knowledge of programming or specialized 3D software. Generating visualizations without this knowledge is a compelling use case.

gpt_4o.polished_text: About two months ago, I went through a truly memorable experience. It happened sometime in July or August when I tried something magical for the first time. This magical experience was due to consuming a few grams of Psilocybin mushrooms. It was nighttime when I gathered everything I needed to try them. I had planned to make a tea from the mushrooms, based on something I read on Reddit. The information suggested that boiling water and letting the mushrooms steep would remove alkaloids causing nausea, though it might weaken the effects. After brewing the tea, I decided to sit down and enjoy my freshly made magical drink. Halfway through the cup, I felt butterflies forming in my stomach. I attributed this feeling to my nerves, as I started to feel anxious about the situation. I had no idea what I should expect or how I would feel. I made the decision to lie down without finishing the tea. This was when the effects began to take hold, about 45 minutes after making the tea. Describing how I felt physically is challenging, but it seemed like I had no energy to get up. I felt as if I were glued to my bed, unable to move. Almost immediately, I became very introspective, reflecting on everything imaginable. I thought about times I got angry and moments when people did things for me. Thoughts about all my family members also crossed my mind. It was a truly remarkable experience, revealing that my perceived problems weren't really problems. I felt as if I had complete control over the world around me, feeling deeply connected to everything. All my everyday stresses vanished, replaced by an overwhelming sense of freedom. This intense experience brought tears to my eyes, and I couldn't stop crying tears of joy. I don't think I've ever felt so free and happy as I did at that moment. I remember telling myself to write down all these feelings, fearful of forgetting them. The next day, I felt an overwhelming glow and wanted to help everyone around me. This experience was incredibly memorable and brought a lot of happiness into my life.

gpt_4o.polished_text: Two months ago, I made the difficult decision to quit my job. We were so short-staffed and overworked that serious safety issues began to arise. Despite this, our supervisor continued to pile on more work. Her boss advised her that some tasks could be skipped, but she ignored the advice, eager to be "number one." Whispers spread among my coworkers, who grew increasingly concerned about their licenses, yet the pressure remained relentless. When I discovered the wrong pills in a bottle, my supervisor was furious, even though I hadn't filled from that bottle all week. The incident was never mentioned again, leaving me sleepless, worrying if other mistakes had gone unnoticed. My job was crucial for my family’s income and my self-worth, but I feared being held liable if something went wrong. The work environment was toxic, with an abusive supervisor notorious for her nastiness. My coworkers trained me through yelling and would argue about me in Spanish. Still, I persisted, determined not to let them win. Each day, I wished for a car accident severe enough to prevent me from working. I became irritable with my husband and child, and every moment outside of work was overshadowed by the dread of returning. My marriage suffered, and my self-esteem plummeted. Yet, I continued until one day, a single Tramadol tablet jolted me awake. A controlled substance had mistakenly been placed in a bottle of blood pressure medication, and no one noticed. The daily counts of controlled substances weren't off, which seemed suspicious. Was someone miscounting, or ignoring the issue to avoid paperwork? How often had this happened before, and why was I blamed? These questions haunted me until I realized I was sacrificing myself for a job that would discard me in a crisis. Fearing potential criminal charges for something I didn't do, I chose to quit. Now, we're relying on food banks and credit to get by, but I know I made the right choice.

trips_4o.polished_text: Distributed word representations, also known as word vectors, have been widely used in natural language processing, leading to state-of-the-art results for many tasks. Publicly available models, pre-trained on massive data sets, have become a standard tool for many NLP applications, primarily in English. While different techniques have been proposed to learn such representations (Collobert and Weston, 2008; Mikolov et al., 2013b; Pennington et al., 2014), all rely on the distributional hypothesis – the idea that the meaning of a word is captured by the contexts in which it appears. Thus, the quality of word vectors directly depends on the amount and quality of data they were trained on. A common source of data to learn word representations, available in numerous languages, is the online encyclopedia Wikipedia, which offers high-quality data for many languages (Al-Rfou et al., 2013). Unfortunately, for many languages, the size of Wikipedia is relatively small and often insufficient to learn high-quality word vectors with comprehensive coverage. An alternative source of large-scale text data is the web and resources such as the Common Crawl, which provides a vast amount of data for many applications. Although the data from these sources is noisier than Wikipedia articles, it is available in larger quantities and offers broader coverage for various applications. In this work, we contribute high-quality word vectors trained on Wikipedia and the Common Crawl corpus. We collected large training corpora for 157 languages using Wikipedia and Common Crawl, as well as other sources. We describe in detail the procedure for splitting the data by language and pre-processing it in Section 2. Using this data, we trained word vectors using an extension of the fastText model with subword information (Bojanowski et al., 2017), as described in Section 3. In Section 4, we introduce three new word analogy datasets for French, Hindi, and Polish, and evaluate our word representations on a variety of word analogy tasks. Overall, we evaluate our word vectors on 10 languages: Czech, German, Spanish, Finnish, French, Hindi, Italian, Polish, Portuguese, and Chinese. Unlike some prior work that uses the Google News dataset, our models for 157 languages utilize training data from Wikipedia, Common Crawl, and other large datasets. In previous work, word vectors pre-trained on large text corpora have been released alongside open-source implementations of word embeddings, such as those from various embedding models. A significant portion of pre-trained word vectors (100B tokens) was published with the word2vec model (Mikolov et al., 2013b). Pennington et al. (2014) released GloVe models trained on Wikipedia, Gigaword, and Common Crawl (840B tokens), which offer a large amount of training data. Where word vectors were trained for 100 languages using Wikipedia data, providing a valuable resource for many applications.

gpt_4o.polished_text: Distributed word representations, often referred to as word vectors, have gained significant traction in the field of natural language processing (NLP). These vectors have led to state-of-the-art results for numerous NLP tasks. Publicly available models, pre-trained on vast datasets, have become indispensable tools in many NLP applications. However, most of these models are primarily available for the English language. Various techniques have been introduced to learn these representations, including works by Collobert and Weston (2008), Mikolov et al. (2013b), and Pennington et al. (2014). All these methods are based on the distributional hypothesis, which suggests that a word's meaning is captured by the contexts in which it appears. Consequently, the quality of word vectors is heavily influenced by the amount and quality of the data used for training. Wikipedia is a common data source for learning word representations and is available in multiple languages. This platform offers high-quality data that is comparable across different languages. Unfortunately, the size of Wikipedia entries for many languages is relatively small, often insufficient for developing high-quality word vectors with extensive coverage. An alternative source of large-scale text data is the web, including resources such as Common Crawl. Although web-based data is noisier compared to Wikipedia articles, it is available in larger quantities and offers broader coverage. In this study, we provide high-quality word vectors trained on both Wikipedia and the Common Crawl corpus. Additionally, we introduce three new word analogy datasets. We compiled training corpora for 157 languages, utilizing both Wikipedia and Common Crawl as our data sources. Detailed procedures for language-specific data splitting and pre-processing are described in Section 2. Using these data sources, we trained word vectors with an extension of the fastText model that incorporates subword information, as detailed in Section 3. In Section 4, we present three new word analogy datasets for French, Hindi, and Polish. We subsequently evaluate our word representations on these word analogy tasks. Overall, our word vectors are evaluated on ten languages: Czech, German, Spanish, Finnish, French, Hindi, Italian, Polish, Portuguese, and Chinese. Our models support 157 languages, excluding English, and are trained using data from the Google News dataset. In previous studies, word vectors pre-trained on extensive text corpora have been released alongside open-source implementations of word embedding models. For example, a part of the English word vectors dataset, containing 100 billion tokens, was published with word2vec by Mikolov et al. (2013b). Pennington et al. (2014) released GloVe models trained on Wikipedia, Gigaword, and Common Crawl, encompassing 840 billion tokens. A significant contribution is the work of Al-Rfou et al. (2013), which involved training word vectors for 100 languages using Wikipedia data.

trips_4o.polished_text: Automatic morphological processing tools have the potential to drastically speed up language documentation (Moeller et al., 2020). They can thereby help combat the language endangerment crisis (Austin and Sallabank, 2011). Explicit morphological information also benefits myriad NLP tasks, such as parsing (Hohensee and Bender, 2012; Seeker, 2015). It also aids language modeling (Blevins and Zettlemoyer, 2019; Park et al., 2021; Hofmann et al., 2021). Additionally, it supports machine translation (Dyer et al., 2008; Tamchyna et al., 2017). For low-resource languages, valuable morphological resources are typically small or non-existent, making it difficult to develop effective language processing tools for these languages. Of late, the field of computational morphology has increased its efforts to extend the coverage of multilingual morphological resources (Kirov et al., 2016, 2018). Researchers like McCarthy et al. (2020a) and Metheniti and Neumann (2020) have contributed to these efforts. Simultaneously, there has been a revival of minimally supervised and unsupervised models for morphological tasks. These include segmentation (Eskander et al., 2019), inflection (Kann et al., 2017b), and lemmatization (Bergmanis and Goldwater, 2019). Given the speed of recent developments, it is important to reflect on our current position as a field and to identify the challenges we face in advancing computational morphology. To this end, we survey recent computational morphology. We review existing multilingual resources (§2) and tasks and systems (§3), with a focus on low-resource languages. Given recent developments in unsupervised segmentation, low-resource morphological inflection, and unsupervised morphological paradigm completion (Jin et al., 2020; Erdmann et al., 2020)—which we argue is not fully unsupervised—there is potential for a significant advancement in the field. We believe the community is poised for the next logical step: inferring a language’s morphology purely from raw text. In §4, we formalize a new task: truly unsupervised morphological paradigm completion (tUMPC), which aims to advance the automatic analysis of language structures without any prior annotations. We then introduce a pipeline with two novel components (§4.3). One model aligns paradigm slots across lexemes. Another model predicts the slots of observed forms. With these components, we assess several state-of-the-art models. We also examine the influence of different types of unlabeled corpora within the framework of tUMPC. While existing methods leave room for improvement, they perform reasonably well. This supports our argument that inferring a language’s morphology from raw text is achievable and worthy of community efforts. To summarize, we present the following contributions: (i) a survey of tasks and systems in computational morphology with a focus on low-resource languages; (ii) models for the tasks of paradigm slot alignment and slot prediction. We also include (iii) a formalization of the task of truly unsupervised morphological paradigm completion and (iv) an evaluation of state-of-the-art approaches and different corpora within the framework of this task. Our code and data are publicly available.
